claim: All fruits grow on trees. Tomatoes grow on trees. So tomatoes are fruits

supporting.text: Botanically, tomatoes are classified as fruits because they develop from the ovary of a flowering plant and contain seeds.

attacks.text: Botanically, tomatoes are classified as fruits because they develop from the ovary of a flowering plant and contain seeds.
Culinary practices commonly treat tomatoes as vegetables due to their savory flavor and typical usage in salads and main dishes, not desserts.
Legal classifications, such as the 1893 U.S. Supreme Court case Nix v. Hedden, ruled tomatoes as vegetables for tariff purposes, reinforcing their non-fruit culinary identity.
Some botanical fruits (e.g., cucumbers, bell peppers) are also treated as vegetables in cooking, showing that botanical and culinary definitions can diverge without invalidating either.
The claim 'all fruits grow on trees' is false—many fruits (e.g., watermelons, strawberries) grow on vines or bushes, undermining the premise linking tomatoes to trees.
